overview: Vote Leave campaign claimed leaving the EU would save £350 million per week for the NHS.
furtherDescription: This figure was printed on the side of the Vote Leave campaign bus, becoming one of the most controversial claims.

overview: Remain campaign argued Brexit would cause an immediate economic shock.
furtherDescription: Chancellor George Osborne warned of a 'DIY recession' if Britain left the EU.

overview: Nigel Farage claimed Brexit would allow the UK to take back control of its borders.
furtherDescription: This was a central message of the Leave campaign, focusing heavily on immigration.

overview: David Cameron argued leaving the EU would threaten national security.
furtherDescription: Cameron suggested that EU membership allowed Britain to work more closely with European allies against terrorism.

overview: Vote Leave highlighted potential trade deals with non-EU countries.
furtherDescription: Leave campaigners argued that the UK could negotiate better trade deals independently.

overview: Remain campaign emphasised freedom of movement benefits for young people.
furtherDescription: They argued that staying in the EU guaranteed British citizens the right to work, study, and travel across Europe.

overview: Michael Gove said Brexit would restore sovereignty to the UK Parliament.
furtherDescription: He claimed too many decisions were being made in Brussels rather than Westminster.

overview: Barack Obama warned the UK would be 'at the back of the queue' for trade deals if it left the EU.
furtherDescription: The US President intervened during his state visit, sparking controversy among Leave supporters.

overview: Boris Johnson argued that the EU was undermining democracy.
furtherDescription: Johnson suggested that decisions affecting Britain should not be made by unelected EU bureaucrats.

overview: Remain campaign launched warnings of house price falls and job losses if Brexit happened.
furtherDescription: Opponents of Brexit argued that leaving would destabilise the housing market and increase unemployment.

overview: Confederation of British Industry (CBI) warned that leaving the EU could cost the UK economy around £100 billion and 950,000 jobs by 2020.
furtherDescription: The CBI commissioned research showing a potential 3-5% hit to GDP and major job losses if the UK left the EU; widely cited by the Remain campaign. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

overview: UK Statistics Authority officially criticised the claim that the UK sends £350 million per week to the EU, calling it misleading.
furtherDescription: In a public statement the Authority noted that the gross figure was not the net contribution and warned its misuse undermines trust in official statistics. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

overview: David Cameron delivered a statement in the House of Commons on 22 February 2016 about his EU reform package and the coming referendum.
furtherDescription: He set out the four reform areas and announced the referendum date for 23 June 2016 as part of the UK’s renegotiated deal. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

overview: In an April 2016 speech at O2 plc in Slough, Cameron argued that deciding to stay or leave the EU was a bigger decision than a general election.
furtherDescription: Cameron told business staff that the referendum decision was ‘much bigger’ than ordinary elections because it would shape the country’s future for decades. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}

overview: Liz Truss told farmers on 23 February 2016 that leaving the EU would be a ‘leap into the dark’ and warned of risks to UK food & farming exports.
furtherDescription: As Environment Secretary she urged farmers to vote to remain, emphasising UK access to the EU’s 500 million consumers and warning of trade barriers. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}

overview: Britain Stronger in Europe (Remain campaign) published a government leaflet in April 2016 warning that a vote to leave the EU could lead to 'a decade or more of uncertainty'.
furtherDescription: The official ‘Stay’ campaign’s leaflet cost £9.3 m and argued Brexit would raise living costs, hit jobs and reduce living standards. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}

overview: In April 2016 the HM Treasury published analysis that voting to leave would make each UK household on average £4,300 worse off per year after 15 years.
furtherDescription: The analysis estimated a GDP reduction of 6.2% and a tax increase equivalent to 8p in the income tax rate. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}

overview: In April 2016 the Remain side highlighted that agricultural subsidies under the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) made up roughly 50-60% of UK farm income and that exit would bring huge uncertainty to farming policy.
furtherDescription: A briefing by the Commons Library noted that UK farms received substantial payments from the EU and that the UK government had offered no full 'Plan B' for agriculture post-exit. :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}

overview: In a campaign rally in May 2016 Michael Gove claimed that the UK would ‘take back control’ of approximately £19 billion a year (equivalent to £350 million a week) if it left the EU.
furtherDescription: Gove asserted decisions were being made in Brussels and argued a Leave vote would restore sovereignty; this formed a core Leave campaign message. :contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}

overview: In June 2016 the Leave campaign emphasised that a Leave vote would allow the UK to secure trade deals globally, independent of EU membership.
furtherDescription: The Leave side argued that outside the EU the UK would be free to negotiate its own trade agreements with non-EU countries. (This mirrors the event you already had, but I include a fuller note.)

overview: A key campaign message in May 2016 by Boris Johnson stated that EU membership undermined British democracy and that decisions affecting the UK should not be made by unelected EU bureaucrats.
furtherDescription: Johnson framed Brexit as reclaiming democracy and saw the EU as a threat to self-government. :contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}
